reviewText: A strategic level-based city building simulator in the vein of the Caesar/Pharoah series of old. It's easy to understand but operates slightly differently from how most others do (where road access between buildings is necessary for benefits), instead opting for a direct distance" approach in order for benefits to convey. Because of this
date: some strategies may seem non-intuitive at first to folks who are experienced in the genre.\n\nIt's competent
recommended: and fun - not the best example of the genre
hoursPlayed: but a good way to spend some time if you're into this type of game."
voteText: February 13, 2014
votesTotal: 47 of 52 people (90%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I enjoy city builders, and I enjoy Civilization, so this one was very exciting for me.

It's really more of a city builder than a Civilization game, though. You can research technologies to unlock new buildings, but it stays in one era (of course), and it has wonders you may build. That's about all for the similarties between Civ and CivCity.

The campaign does a good job of easing you into building a city, introducing you to new buildings little by little. I kept expecting it to end, but it ended up being a fairly deep game, the ending having quite a lot of buildings and rescources to manage. I had a lot of fun, especially at the end when I had to make my city pretty with gardens and statues in order to win the game.
voteText: 33 of 35 people (94%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
City Building and Civilization come together in this city-state based game. Build your settlement from just a few huts into a detailed and thriving center of trade, conquest and research. The game reminds me alot of the ANNO series where you have settlers that come into your city, you have to fill certain needs, and they level up. A player can choose from a free-build city, to doing the campaign, and even beyond to playing your own custom maps that YOU as a player can create.

A few things I have noticed that are not accurate, is that aquaduct technology allowed for one main trunk to branch into smaller segments, in this game that does not occur so you do not get the representation of the True aquaduct system. However the gameplay was not affected by this.

One thing that I do NOT like about it is that I found the maps to be small. I mean really small. I constantly had a high unemployment. Apparently settlers just come in even if there is no spare work slots. And the workers dont leave if you bulldoze work places if you move them. Documented sources via gametap.com/formus have stated that when happiness is positibe
date:
immigrants arrive reguardless of housing and cause unemployment and housing chrises" With this said its kinda broken in a sence if you have 100% happiness you will always have a high unemployment.

Another thing is that widescreen support is not automatically built into the game on download. (As also documented in steam forums) HOWEVER there are fixes and solutions for this that can be found on google.

Now then for the positives. It is a simple game. The menus are easy to navigate
recommended: and the gameplay is easy and quick to comprehend. For example Wheat farm -> Wheat -> Mill -> Flour -> Bakery -> Bread.  Another thing is that it IS addictive. looking at my clock I played 3-4 hours on one map straight through. Please remember to set yourself a timer when you play this game I will not be responsible if you spend 3 whole days on the game and forget to eat or sleep. Yes it is that addicting.\n\nOther thoughts : I wish widescreen resolution was included with the game. I wish there was alot more realism
hoursPlayed: for example you cant build on mountains.. Yet the alps are in the north
voteText:
and the apennine run through the center. I am quite sure the Romans found a way around that.

Overall : Would recommend. Due to price. Recommend x 1.5 .. H/N Kinsha review rates this AS.... 4.25 cookes OUT of 5 cookies.

I am Natalia Kinsha and I approve this message ^.^"
votesFunny: 34 of 37 people (92%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText: I got this game because it reminded me of Pharaoh and Master of Olympus:Zeus, which I spent plenty of hours on when I was younger. I wasn't disappointed, I enjoyed building my cities which could grow quite quickly once you have managed to start making good money. I found some difficulty when I first realised that when the houses evolved they needed to be rehomed and I had to do a lot of remapping of my city to fit in my estates. My own fault for not checking the tutorial before each campaign mission.\nIt's all about balance. Big cities can be hard to manage if you haven't got the means to meet everyones needs. Also vagrants don't stop coming, by trying to house all your workers more vagrants come to the citie even if you don't have the jobs for them. This doesn't stop you from being able to play the game, it is only a slight annoyance in that you can't really create a perfect city.\nIt also has a military side to it for those who would like it, adding another level in the game. Trying to keep yourself well defended whilst also keeping your city happy and growing adds the next difficulty to the game.

reviewText: Although I've only played this game for a few hours on steam, I can assure you that I've racked up more time playing this game, as I've still got the hard copy from when it first came out from 2006, and let that be an indicator of how good of a game this is.  To start with, the game is very simplistic in design and approach, but don't let that fool you into think this game is easy.  To put it simply, it is relaxing but challenging, but the challenge can be set harder if you want to try at a much more diffcult level.  But overall, this game is a pleasure, and, I should think I will play many more hours to this game for many years to come.

reviewText: Oldie but goodie. The number of Rome-themed city-building games is oddly high, but this one is my favorite. Not for anyone who likes the RTS/combat aspect, as that part is rubbish here. But if not, it can be really fun, at least through the campaign. The stand-alone scenarios have limited replayability, and though you CAN make your own maps (and campaigns!) the tool to do so is not user friendly and there are some bugs in it. Overall though, a great way to spend some time building & managing, especially for the price.

reviewText: I love Civ and I love City simulations, I'm very familiar with this game genre.  CivCity Rome is pretty good, but it has some bug that need to be addressed.  I've played 31 hours over the last two weeks, and I have found some minor bugs in the game. Sometimes, but workers sleep in when its work time.  My docks unload very slowly or not at all. Why wont my houses improve when they are surrounded by plenty of services.  I would like to see overlays to see which building are negatively affecting my houses, is that the problem? Citizens seem to get stuck in ruts and ingore the bath or food they need to improve housing, even though there is plenty in the city and near by.\nI like the game, but I'm barely in the 4/5 part of the campaign and I've spend many hours just trying to past basic hurtles.  Maybe I dont yet understand the game mechanics.  I have not given up, but at this point I can't recommend other people buy the game until the bugs are fixed or explained.  Something is not working consistantly.

reviewText:
I'm not sure if I paid money for this or if it came free in a bundle, because it's been in my library for a while.  I hope the latter, because while it looks cute and seems to play decently at first, everything begins to unravel as soon as the scenarios get a tiny bit more challenging.  By the time I was playing Britannia, I realised that there was only superficial control of basic economic functions and none of the things that I wanted and needed to do were possible.

I could tell a warehouse to send  one commodity to another warehouse, but I couldn't tell workers to stop gathering the raw resource (the only way to control a glut of supply was to demolish the worker's station).  I couldn't prioritse manufacturing at any particular workshop (Settlers could do that 20 years ago, so...really?)  I couldn't manage workforce supply and demand by assigning additional carriers either.

Even basic functionality was missing.  For example, there is no prompt, visual or verbal, to tell you that one of your residences is either devolving due to lack of desired resources or needing intervention in order to evolve.   The first one in the tutorial is brought to your attention, but that's it.

There are only verbal prompts (hard luck if you are a hard of hearing games player who uses captions) and no other sign of something wrong when granaries and warehouses get full, or when food is close to running out.

You cannot even zoom out to see the whole map at a glance and half of every single map is unusable due to bumpy terrain, with no option to do anything about this.

So I rate this game as frustrating and annoying once the initial charm wears off. I did however laugh quite heartily at Spartacus and his East London accent.  I kept waiting for him to break out into full Cockney or steal a diamond or a rare pair of flintlock muskets.  Sadly, I was disappointed in that as well.

reviewText:
This is a lovely little game. The free to play nature and the pleasant music makes for many hours of imaginative creativity. I remember playing this when it was release many years ago, it was one of my favourite games.

Although I would say that there are some issues to the game. The first one being the fact that things get quite boring once you've mastered the correct technique to expand your city and improve your hovels.

Another issue, (although this may be a one off") is the occasional failure of avatars to carry out their work. For example
recommended: the firemen and the tunic weaver tend to either sleep or wait about instead of work. This is a significant problem because it means I am unable to progress through the campaign
hoursPlayed: and it also halts any chance of progression.\n\nAside from these pointers
voteText: it's a lovely game (if you're lucky to not have these issues)."

reviewText:
A fantastic city builder, the quality is high enough to feel like a civic spin off from the Age of series. The replay value is very high, with a civic and a military campaign, single mission options, a map editor, and of course, various skill levels to challenge yourself with. For being a game from 2006, it plays extremely well. While the graphics aren't stunning, they are on par with the already mentioned Age of series.


If you like city builders, RTS, Rome, or economic games then give this a try.

reviewText: A few Hours in and I tell you that for fans of Caesar IV, Pharaoh, or Emperor Rise of the Middle Kingdom, this game is right up your alley.  You play the clever city builder in the employ of the Roman goverment to seek out new areas and found new cities from the ground up.  Each scenario becomes increasingly difficult, but not to the point that it becomes overly taxing to build and maintain your city.  There are fewer overlays in this game, making it slightly harder to micro manage your city as perfectly as you might have in previous city builders of the same genre.  Still, you command all the power on your map, and if a Roman's house has to go for the city bath, you just say the word.  There are also economic and military scenarios available as you progress into the game, as you might have assumed.\n\nThere are only a few negative aspects of the game that might make the avid city builder a little frustrated.  In CivCity: Rome, you find yourself balancing happiness constantly.  The scale goes from +100 to -100 and it affects your population directly.  If you leave your happiness at +100 (which is relatively easy to do in most scenarios) your population will explode leading to vagrants" that sit outside your town center
recommended: and generate... unhappiness.  On its own
voteText: but you'll eventually find yourself trying to balance your population by keeping your happiness in the -10 to +10 range
helpfulPercent: which equals 0 growth and 0 loss.  If you then want to create a new industry
votesHelpful: you'll need to bump your happiness to get more people
votesTotal: then bring it back down again.  Occassionally you'll receive empire bonuses or
commentsCount: barbarian threats that will mess with your happiness for a short time.  I found this yo-yo effect to be a little annoying at times.\n\nPostively
column16: Sid has added some researchable technologies that you can use to customize your city to the style you want for the particular map your on
column17: which is really refreshing.  This game is really a solid add to your collection if you like these types of city builders."

reviewText: Great game as it was made from two great developers, Firefly (Stronghold Series) and Firaxis (XCOM:EU/EW, Civilazation Series). It has a mix of both developers such as researching technologies from Firaxis and the city building from Firefly. There is a small portion of combat gameplay but not on a grand scale or as broad as such from the Stronghold or Civ Series.\nI would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a sim city builder with the concepts from Firefly and Firaxis.

reviewText: I managed to pick this up on the Humble Bundle summer sale for about $2.50.  At that price, I don't feel too bad about it.  It is an old game.  I might have enjoyed it a bit more at the time, but now I've played much better, similar games.  I've played other games from this company (and others from about that era) that run on my widescreen monitor is just fine.  Here, not so much.  You can edit a config file to set the resolution manually, but there's still so little visible game space that placing some of the larger buildings, like a circus means you can't even see the whole footprint to place it.\n\nBottom line - I really wish I had done a little research, even for spending $2.50.   I'll see it through to satisfy  my must finish" mentality

reviewText: I would not get this game if you are looking for a competitive fast pace game. I would get it if you just want to relax and have some fun. In this game you just make a city and watch your people work. You can make gladiators or chariot races. Or you can just watch the smith make a sword. The problem with this game is that it doesn't have a bigger idea to it. Once  you run out of space you are done.\nI would deffinetley reccomened this game
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: A few Hours in and I tell you that for fans of Caesar IV, Pharaoh, or Emperor Rise of the Middle Kingdom, this game is right up your alley.  You play the clever city builder in the employ of the Roman goverment to seek out new areas and found new cities from the ground up.  Each scenario becomes increasingly difficult, but not to the point that it becomes overly taxing to build and maintain your city.  There are fewer overlays in this game, making it slightly harder to micro manage your city as perfectly as you might have in previous city builders of the same genre.  Still, you command all the power on your map, and if a Roman's house has to go for the city bath, you just say the word.  There are also economic and military scenarios available as you progress into the game, as you might have assumed.\n\nThere are only a few negative aspects of the game that might make the avid city builder a little frustrated.  In CivCity: Rome, you find yourself balancing happiness constantly.  The scale goes from +100 to -100 and it affects your population directly.  If you leave your happiness at +100 (which is relatively easy to do in most scenarios) your population will explode leading to vagrants" that sit outside your town center
recommended: and generate... unhappiness.  On its own
voteText: but you'll eventually find yourself trying to balance your population by keeping your happiness in the -10 to +10 range
helpfulPercent: which equals 0 growth and 0 loss.  If you then want to create a new industry
votesHelpful: you'll need to bump your happiness to get more people
votesTotal: then bring it back down again.  Occassionally you'll receive empire bonuses or
commentsCount: barbarian threats that will mess with your happiness for a short time.  I found this yo-yo effect to be a little annoying at times.\n\nPostively
column16: Sid has added some researchable technologies that you can use to customize your city to the style you want for the particular map your on
column17: which is really refreshing.  This game is really a solid add to your collection if you like these types of city builders."

reviewText: I had this game on a disc 5-6 years ago, but the disc broke 'bout 3 years ago. It's a great game, I'll admit that, but I wish this game's engine worked on a Windows 8 system. Waste of money if you are buying it on a Windows 8, which is probably the worst of it's kind in systems.\n\nEdit: My old system only had 2 gigs of ram, my newer 6 gig runs it great.

reviewText: Civ City may once upon a time have been a mediocre game. It has since aged very badly indeed, the graphics are poor, the interface is annoying and the gameplay is uninspiring to say the least. If you are interested in something of the Roman era then try Grand Ages: Rome instead.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Short, but sweet. I completed it within about 7-8 hours, but it is quite an intriguing game similar to the Caesar series. I'd recommend it as a throwaway game... it's certainly not as deep as Caesar III is, but it provides a bit of interest for a few hours.

reviewText:
i went out on a whim and bought this game. never heard of it, never seen it, obviously never played it.

what a total barn find! this game is absoluetly amazing. i loved the caesar series to death and was hoping to find something at least somewhat similar. Low and behold i did. Not excatly the same. many great difference. but easy to understand, super relaxing, and tons of fun.

into city building/ management? buy this game!

reviewText: Great game as it was made from two great developers, Firefly (Stronghold Series) and Firaxis (XCOM:EU/EW, Civilazation Series). It has a mix of both developers such as researching technologies from Firaxis and the city building from Firefly. There is a small portion of combat gameplay but not on a grand scale or as broad as such from the Stronghold or Civ Series.\nI would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a sim city builder with the concepts from Firefly and Firaxis.

reviewText: I play RTS and had not heard of this one. It is surprisingly good. Like Banished. You quickly see everything there is to see, then try your skills against the challenges. Easy has very little detail and hard requires attention to detail. I wish I could set the amount of each good allowed into a warehouse and granary. And there's a lot that is not explained in game, such as why people revolt, effects of wonders. Otherwise very very good.

reviewText:
Ok so it turns out that the game decided to start crashing on startup for no apparent reason.

Also, any properties you change (such as running in compatibility mode) will cause the game to give the error Failed to find steam". And there is no documentation of fixing this problem because no one plays CivCity: Rome.

[DATA EXPUNGED]
Playable on widescreen monitors (though there seems to be no support for it) and runs stable on modern computers.

CivCity: Rome is a city builder. If you like city builders
awesome game\nwhats sad is there is no one making these types of games anymore.
